open_questions.title: TypeScript
open_questions.description: What is TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: TypeScript is a statically-typed programming language developed by Microsoft. It extends JavaScript by adding a type system, allowing developers to specify data types for variables, function parameters, and return values. This helps catch errors early in the development process and makes code more robust and maintainable. TypeScript is transpiled into JavaScript, making it compatible with all JavaScript environments, and it's commonly used in web development for building scalable and reliable applications.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: List the benefits of TypeScript.
open_questions.description: List the benefits of TypeScript.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "List the benefits of TypeScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Strong Typing: TypeScript's ability to explicitly define variable types improves code quality and reliability. It reduces the likelihood of runtime errors by catching type-related issues during development. Code Clarity and Maintainability: By enforcing type definitions, TypeScript makes the code more readable and easier to understand, which is particularly beneficial in large codebases or team environments. Object-Oriented Features: TypeScript supports object-oriented programming features like classes, interfaces, and inheritance, making it easier to organize and manage code. Improved Tooling and IDE Support: TypeScript's strong typing allows for better tooling support, including more powerful autocompletion, navigation, and refactoring capabilities. Compatibility with JavaScript: TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript, meaning any valid JavaScript code is also valid TypeScript. This makes it easy to adopt incrementally and use with existing JavaScript codebases. Early Error Detection: TypeScript's compiler can detect errors at compile-time rather than at runtime, leading to more robust code and faster debugging.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: List the disadvantages of TypeScript.
open_questions.description: List the disadvantages of TypeScript.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "List the disadvantages of TypeScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Learning Curve: For developers not familiar with strongly typed languages, there's a learning curve to understand TypeScript's typing system. Additional Complexity: TypeScript adds additional complexity with its types and interfaces, which can be a hindrance for small projects or simple applications. Compilation Step: TypeScript code needs to be compiled to JavaScript, adding an extra step in the development process. Potentially Verbose: Typing can make code more verbose, particularly when defining complex types or interfaces. Tooling Requirement: Effective use of TypeScript requires appropriate tooling, which might not be readily available or integrated into all development environments. Adoption in Existing Projects: Integrating TypeScript into an existing JavaScript project can be challenging, especially if the project is large and complex.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Static typing.
open_questions.description: Define static typing.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Define static typing.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Static typing in programming refers to a feature where the type of a variable (such as an integer, string, etc.) is known and checked at compile-time, before the program is run. This contrasts with dynamic typing, where variable types are typically understood and can change during runtime.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: To declare a variable in TypeScript
open_questions.description: How to declare a variable in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "How to declare a variable in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, declaring a variable is similar to how it's done in JavaScript, but with the addition of type annotations. Here's the basic syntax: let variableName: Type = value; let (or const for constants, var for function-scoped variables) is the keyword used to declare a variable. variableName is the name of the variable. Type is the TypeScript type of the variable (like number, string, boolean, etc.). value is the initial value assigned to the variable.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name the access modifiers supported in
open_questions.description: Name the access modifiers supported in TypeScript.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name the access modifiers supported in TypeScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: TypeScript supports several access modifiers to control the visibility and accessibility of class members (properties and methods). These are: Public: This is the default access level. Public members are accessible from anywhere without any restrictions. They can be accessed from outside the class, from derived classes, and within the class itself. class Example { public publicProperty: string; } Private: Private members are accessible only within the class that defines them. They cannot be accessed from outside of the class or by derived classes. class Example { private privateProperty: string; } Protected: Protected members are accessible within the class and by classes that are derived from it. However, they are not accessible from outside these classes. class Example { protected protectedProperty: string; } Readonly: This is not exactly an access modifier but a modifier that can be used in conjunction with the above access modifiers. It makes a property read-only, meaning it can be assigned a value only during declaration or within the constructor of the same class. class Example { readonly readonlyProperty: string; }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The use of the tsconfig.json file
open_questions.description: What is the use of the tsconfig.json file?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the use of the tsconfig.json file?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The tsconfig.json file in TypeScript is a crucial configuration file used to specify how the TypeScript compiler (tsc) should compile TypeScript code into JavaScript. It serves several important purposes: Compiler Options: It allows you to set various compiler options, such as the target JavaScript version (e.g., ES5, ES6), module system (e.g., CommonJS, ES Modules), strictness settings, and more. These options enable you to control the behavior of the compiler and the features it supports. Project Structure: It helps define the structure of your TypeScript project. You can specify which files and directories should be included or excluded from the compilation process. Type Checking Rules: TypeScript offers a set of type checking options that can be configured in tsconfig.json. This includes enabling strict type checking, implicit any checks, strict null checks, and others, which help in writing more robust and error-free code. Source Maps: You can configure the generation of source maps, which help in debugging the TypeScript code after it's been compiled to JavaScript.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: What type inference is in TypeScript.
open_questions.description: Explain what type inference is in TypeScript.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain what type inference is in TypeScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Type inference in TypeScript is the ability of the TypeScript compiler to automatically deduce or determine the data type of a variable or expression without explicitly specifying it. TypeScript analyzes your code and infers the type based on how you've used variables and values. This feature allows you to write code with less explicit type annotations while still benefiting from the benefits of static typing. Example: let numberValue = 42; // TypeScript infers the type "number" for numberValue let stringValue = "Hello"; // TypeScript infers the type "string" for stringValue function add(a, b) { return a + b; } const result = add(10, 20); // TypeScript infers the type of "result" as "number"
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between interface and type
open_questions.description: Explain the difference between interface and type alias in TypeScript.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the difference between interface and type alias in TypeScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, both interfaces and type aliases are used to define custom data types, but they have some differences: Syntax: Interface: Interfaces are defined using the interface keyword. They describe the shape of an object or class. Type Alias: Type aliases are defined using the type keyword. They can represent any type, not just objects, and are more flexible. Extending/Implementing: Interface: Interfaces can be extended by other interfaces using the extends keyword, and classes can implement interfaces. Type Alias: Type aliases cannot be extended or implemented. They are standalone and represent specific types. Compatibility: Interface: Interfaces are open-ended by default. If you declare an interface with a certain structure, you can later add more properties to it without causing issues. Type Alias: Type aliases create exact types. Once defined, you cannot add or change properties to the type without breaking compatibility. Union and Intersection: Interface: Interfaces are not suitable for creating union or intersection types directly. Type Alias: Type aliases can be used to create union types (|) and intersection types (&) more easily. Example: // Interface interface Person { name: string; age: number; } // Extending an interface interface Employee extends Person { employeeId: string; } // Type alias type Person = { name: string; age: number; }; // Creating a union type with a type alias type StringOrNumber = string | number;
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A type guard in TypeScript, and
open_questions.description: What is a type guard in TypeScript, and how does it help narrow down types?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a type guard in TypeScript, and how does it help narrow down types?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A type guard is a TypeScript function or expression that checks and narrows down the type of a value within a certain code block. Common type guards include typeof, instanceof, and custom user-defined functions. function isString(value: any): value is string { return typeof value === "string"; } let data: any = "Hello, TypeScript!"; if (isString(data)) { // TypeScript knows 'data' is a string here. console.log(data.length); }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The TypeScript Compiler (tsc) and how
open_questions.description: What is the TypeScript Compiler (tsc) and how does it work? Explain the process of compiling TypeScript code to JavaScript.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the TypeScript Compiler (tsc) and how does it work? Explain the process of compiling TypeScript code to JavaScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The TypeScript Compiler (tsc) is a command-line tool used to transpile TypeScript code into JavaScript code. The compilation process involves several steps: Type Checking: The TypeScript compiler checks the TypeScript code for type errors and performs type inference to determine variable types. Emitting JavaScript: After successful type checking, the compiler generates equivalent JavaScript code. The generated code adheres to the specified ECMAScript version (e.g., ES5, ES6). Output Files: The compiled JavaScript code can be output to one or more JavaScript files, preserving the directory structure of the source code. Declaration Files (Optional): Declaration files (with a .d.ts extension) can also be generated to provide type information for TypeScript consumers of JavaScript libraries. Module Resolution: If the code uses modules, the compiler resolves module dependencies and ensures that imported modules are available. Source Maps (Optional): Optionally, source maps can be generated to map the compiled JavaScript code back to the original TypeScript source code for debugging. To compile TypeScript code, you typically run the tsc command with the TypeScript source files as arguments.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A class constant be implemented in
open_questions.description: How can a class constant be implemented in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "How can a class constant be implemented in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, class constants can be implemented using static readonly modifiers. These modifiers are used together to create properties that are constant at the class level. This means they belong to the class itself rather than to instances of the class, and their values cannot be altered once set. Example: class MyClass { static readonly CONSTANT_NAME: Type = value; } console.log(MyClass.CONSTANT_NAME); static means the property belongs to the class itself, not to instances of the class. readonly ensures that the property's value cannot be changed after its initial assignment. CONSTANT_NAME is the name of your constant. By convention, constants are often written in uppercase. Type is the TypeScript type of the constant (like number, string, boolean, etc.). value is the value assigned to the constant.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Tuples in TypeScript are an array-like structure where each element in the array can have a specific type. Unlike regular arrays where all elements typically have the same type, tuples allow for a mixture of different types, with each position in the tuple having a fixed, designated type. This feature is particularly useful when you want to return multiple values from a function or when you need to group together a few values with different types. let user: [number, string] = [1, "John"];

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The never type in TypeScript.
open_questions.description: Explain the never type in TypeScript.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the never type in TypeScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The never type represents values that never occur. It's often inferred in situations like functions that throw errors or enter infinite loops. Practical use cases include exhaustive checking in discriminated unions and functions that never return (e.g., an exception-throwing function). Example: // Functions that never return function throwError(message: string): never { throw new Error(message); } function infiniteLoop(): never { while (true) {} }

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: An enum in TypeScript is a set of named values with a numeric backing. It's similar to an object or dictionary in JavaScript, but it provides type safety and readability. Enums are often used for defining a set of related constant values, such as days of the week or HTTP status codes. enum LogLevel { Error = "ERROR", Warning = "WARNING", Info = "INFO", } const error: LogLevel = LogLevel.Error; // "ERROR"

open_questions.title: The null and undefined type in
open_questions.description: What is the null and undefined type in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a entry-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the null and undefined type in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, both null and undefined are types that represent special values indicating the absence of a meaningful value. They are used to handle cases where a variable or expression does not have a valid or defined value. However there are subtle differences. null Type: The null type represents the intentional absence of any object value or a deliberate assignment of "no value." let myValue: null = null; undefined Type: The undefined type represents the absence of a value due to the variable or property being declared but not assigned any value. let myValue: undefined = undefined;
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: A union type allows a variable to have multiple types. It's defined using the | symbol. Union types are useful when a variable can accept different data types. let value: string | number; value = "Hello"; // Valid value = 42; // Valid

open_questions.title: Intersection types in TypeScript, and how
open_questions.description: What are intersection types in TypeScript, and how do they differ from union types?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are intersection types in TypeScript, and how do they differ from union types?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, intersection types allow you to combine multiple types into a single type, representing values that have all the characteristics of each type involved. Intersection types are denoted by the & (ampersand) operator. They are used to create more complex types by merging two or more types, making them stricter and more specific. type CombinedType = Type1 & Type2;
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Mapped types in TypeScript
open_questions.description: What are mapped types in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are mapped types in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, mapped types are a powerful feature that allow you to create new types by transforming or modifying the properties of existing types. Mapped types are particularly useful for generating new types based on existing ones, often used for scenarios like creating read-only versions of objects, optionalizing properties, or changing property types. Mapped types are defined using the keyof and in keywords in combination with type operations. Example: type MappedType = { [Property in SourceType]: NewType; }; Property: This represents the name of the property in the resulting type. SourceType: This is the type whose properties you want to transform or modify. NewType: This specifies the new type of the property in the resulting type.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: TypeScript uses async and await to work with asynchronous operations in a more readable and structured manner. async is used to define a function that returns a promise, and await is used to pause the execution of a function until the promise is resolved. async function fetchData() { const response = await fetch('https://api.example.com/data'); const data = await response.json(); return data; }

Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Void, and when to use the
open_questions.description: What is void, and when to use the void type?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is void, and when to use the void type?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, void is a type that represents the absence of any value. It is commonly used as the return type of functions that do not return a value. In other words, if a function is intended to perform an action but not return anything, you would annotate it with void. The most common use of void is as the return type for functions that do not return anything. For example: function logMessage(message: string): void { console.log(message); }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Optional chaining in TypeScript
open_questions.description: What is optional chaining in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is optional chaining in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Optional chaining in TypeScript is a language feature that allows for safe navigation of nested object properties or method calls by using the ?. operator. It addresses the issue of potentially encountering null or undefined values when accessing properties or calling methods on objects. With optional chaining, if any part of the chain is null or undefined, the expression short-circuits, and the result is also null or undefined, preventing runtime errors. const person = { name: 'Alice', address: { city: 'New York', zipcode: '10001' } }; const city = person.address?.city; // Safe access, city will be 'New York' const country = person.address?.country; // Safe access, country is undefined
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Mixins
open_questions.description: What are mixins?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are mixins?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Mixins in programming, including in TypeScript, are a design pattern that allows you to create classes which combine behaviors or functionalities from multiple parent classes or objects. They are used to overcome the limitations of single inheritance by enabling a form of multiple inheritance or composition. Mixins allow you to "mix in" additional properties or methods into a class. Example: // A mixin function that adds a timestamp to a class function Timestamped<T extends { new (...args: any[]): {} }>(Base: T) { return class extends Base { timestamp = Date.now(); }; } // A base class class User { name: string; constructor(name: string) { this.name = name; } } // Creating a class from a mixin const TimestampedUser = Timestamped(User); // Using the new class const user = new TimestampedUser("Alice"); console.log(user.name); // Alice console.log(user.timestamp); // A timestamp value In this example, the Timestamped function is a mixin that adds a timestamp property to any class. It is used to create a new class TimestampedUser which has both the properties and methods of User as well as the added timestamp property from the mixin.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of keyof in TypeScript
open_questions.description: What is the purpose of keyof in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the purpose of keyof in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The keyof keyword in TypeScript is used to create a union type of all possible keys in an object type. It's often used to create type-safe code when working with object properties. interface Person { name: string; age: number; } type PersonKeys = keyof Person; // "name" | "age"
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: "conditional types" in TypeScript
open_questions.description: What are "conditional types" in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are "conditional types" in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Conditional types in TypeScript allow you to create type mappings based on the characteristics of other types. They are defined using the extends keyword and conditional expressions. Basic Syntax: type MyConditionalType<T> = T extends U ? X : Y; T is the type parameter you're checking. U is a type you're comparing T to. X is the type that MyConditionalType resolves to when T extends U. Y is the type that MyConditionalType resolves to when T does not extend U.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Distributive conditional types
open_questions.description: What are distributive conditional types?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are distributive conditional types?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Distributive Conditional Types in TypeScript are a powerful feature that allows you to apply a conditional type to each member of a union type individually. This feature becomes particularly useful when you want to transform types based on certain conditions. Example: type ConditionalType = T extends U ? X : Y; Here, T extends U is the condition: if T is assignable to U, then the type will be X; otherwise, it will be Y.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of discriminated unions in
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of discriminated unions in TypeScript.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of discriminated unions in TypeScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Discriminated unions, also known as tagged unions or algebraic data types, are a TypeScript and programming language feature that allows you to create complex type structures by combining multiple types into a single type. Discriminated unions are distinguished by a shared property called a discriminant, which helps TypeScript determine which specific type within the union is currently in use. Example: type Shape = { kind: 'circle'; radius: number; } | { kind: 'rectangle'; width: number; height: number; }; function getArea(shape: Shape): number { switch (shape.kind) { case 'circle': return Math.PI * shape.radius ** 2; case 'rectangle': return shape.width * shape.height; default: // TypeScript ensures all cases are handled const exhaustiveCheck: never = shape; return exhaustiveCheck; } } In this example, the Shape type is a discriminated union consisting of two variants: circle and rectangle. The kind property serves as the discriminant. The getArea function uses a switch statement to determine the specific type within the union based on the kind property and calculates the area accordingly.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The "non-nullable assertion operator" (!) in
open_questions.description: What is the "non-nullable assertion operator" (!) in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the "non-nullable assertion operator" (!) in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The non-nullable assertion operator (!) in TypeScript tells the compiler that a variable or property is guaranteed to be non-null or non-undefined, even if the compiler cannot infer it. It should be used with caution when you're certain that a value won't be null or undefined to avoid runtime errors. function greet(name: string | null): string { // Use the non-nullable assertion operator to assert that 'name' is not null return `Hello, ${name!}!`; // 'name!' asserts that 'name' is not null } const result1 = greet("Alice"); // Valid, 'name' is a non-null string const result2 = greet(null); // Valid, but potentially risky
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Recursive types in TypeScript are types that refer to themselves in their own definition. They are often used to model data structures like trees or linked lists. Here's an example of a recursive type for a binary tree: Example: type TreeNode<T> = { value: T; left?: TreeNode<T>; right?: TreeNode<T>; };

referenceAnswers.text: Type predicates in TypeScript are functions that assert the type of a value and narrow it down within the function's scope. They are often used with the is keyword to check if a value matches a specific type. function isString(value: any): value is string { return typeof value === 'string'; } if (isString(someValue)) { // 'someValue' is now recognized as 'string' type. console.log(someValue.length); }

open_questions.title: The purpose of noImplicitAny
open_questions.description: What is the purpose of noImplicitAny?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the purpose of noImplicitAny?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The noImplicitAny flag in TypeScript is a compiler option that, when enabled, ensures that the type any is not implicitly assigned to variables, parameters, and function return types when their type is not explicitly declared and cannot be inferred from the context. The primary purpose of this flag is to enforce stronger type checking, thereby catching potential errors or ambiguities in the code at compile time. // Without noImplicitAny function add(a, b) { return a + b; } // With noImplicitAny function add(a, b) { return a + b; // Error: Parameter 'a' implicitly has an 'any' type. }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: The unknown type in TypeScript represents a type-safe counterpart to the any type. While any allows you to assign any value to a variable without type checking, unknown requires you to perform type checks or type assertions before using the value. It's recommended to use unknown when you need to work with values of unknown or untrusted types and want to maintain type safety.

open_questions.title: Meant by contextual typing
open_questions.description: What is meant by contextual typing?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is meant by contextual typing?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Contextual typing in TypeScript refers to the TypeScript compiler's ability to infer the type of an expression based on its context. This means the context in which a value is used can influence its type without the need for explicit type annotations. This feature is particularly useful for making the code more concise and readable while still benefiting from TypeScript's strong typing capabilities. interface Event { message: string; } function handleEvent(event: Event) { console.log(event.message); } // In a callback, TypeScript knows the type of 'e' is Event document.addEventListener("click", (e) => handleEvent(e));
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The extensions .ts and .tsx differ
open_questions.description: How do the extensions .ts and .tsx differ in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "How do the extensions .ts and .tsx differ in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, .ts files are standard files for writing TypeScript code, suitable for scripts or applications without JSX syntax. Conversely, .tsx files are used specifically when incorporating JSX syntax, commonly employed in React development for embedding HTML/XML-like code within TypeScript. The TypeScript compiler treats .tsx files differently, enabling it to correctly parse the JSX elements. Trying to use JSX in a .ts file will result in compilation errors, as the compiler does not expect or understand JSX in these files. Thus, the choice between .ts and .tsx hinges on whether or not the file includes JSX code.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: "type-safe nullish coalescing" in TypeScript
open_questions.description: What is "type-safe nullish coalescing" in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is "type-safe nullish coalescing" in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Type-safe nullish coalescing in TypeScript is an enhancement of the nullish coalescing operator (??) that ensures type-specific safety when providing default values for nullable or undefined variables. It only uses the default value when the variable is explicitly null or undefined, preventing unintentional fallbacks for other falsy values. Example: const result = variable ?? defaultValue; This example will assign defaultValue to result only when variable is null or undefined, not for other falsy values like 0 or false.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Scope variable
open_questions.description: What is Scope variable?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is Scope variable?" Requirements: - Function scope vs block scope - `var` vs `let`/`const` behavior Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Function scope vs block scope; var vs let/const behavior. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, a scope variable's accessibility is determined by where it is declared, which can either be within a specific block (local scope) or outside any block (global scope). Local scope variables, declared within functions or blocks using let or const, are accessible only within those blocks and cannot be accessed from outside. Global scope variables, declared outside any function or block, are accessible from any part of the program. TypeScript, following JavaScript's scoping rules, allows for clear and manageable variable scopes to prevent naming conflicts and unintended interactions. let globalVar = "Accessible globally"; function testScope() { let localVar = "Accessible only in this function"; console.log(globalVar); // Works fine console.log(localVar); // Works fine } testScope(); console.log(globalVar); // Works fine console.log(localVar); // Error: localVar is not defined outside testScope
keyPoints: Function scope vs block scope
`var` vs `let`/`const` behavior

They are defined using string literal values as type annotations. type Fruit = 'apple' | 'banana' | 'orange'; function eat(fruit: Fruit): void { console.log(`Eating a ${fruit}`); } eat('apple'); // Valideat('grape'); // Error: Argument of type '"grape"' is not assignable to parameter of type 'Fruit'.

open_questions.title: The purpose of the "key remapping"

open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the purpose of the "key remapping" feature in mapped types in TypeScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.

referenceAnswers.text: Key remapping in mapped types allows you to create a new type by transforming or renaming the keys of an existing type. It's achieved by using the in keyword and defining new keys. Example: type RenameKeys<T> = { [K in keyof T as `new_${K}`]: T[K]; }; type Original = { foo: string; bar: number }; type Renamed = RenameKeys<Original>; // { new_foo: string; new_bar: number }

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Declaration files (.d.ts) in TypeScript are used to declare the types and interfaces for external JavaScript libraries or modules that lack type definitions. They provide type information for TypeScript when working with JavaScript code. Example: // math-lib.d.tsdeclare module 'math-lib' { export function add(x: number, y: number): number; export function subtract(x: number, y: number): number; }

referenceAnswers.text: The as const assertion in TypeScript is used to create read-only literal types from values. It tells TypeScript to infer the most specific literal type for the expression. Example: const colors = ['red', 'green', 'blue'] as const; // 'colors' is of type: ['red', 'green', 'blue'] function getColor(color: typeof colors[number]) { // 'color' can only be one of the literal values in 'colors' return color; }

open_questions.title: An anonymous function in TypeScript
open_questions.description: What is an anonymous function in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is an anonymous function in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: An anonymous function in TypeScript, as in JavaScript, is a function that is defined without a name. Anonymous functions are often used in situations where a function is used as an argument to another function, or assigned to a variable, and a name is not needed or would not add clarity to the code. They are commonly used in callbacks, event handlers, and with promises. // Example using an arrow function: let myFunction = () => { console.log("Hello from an anonymous function!"); };
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Getters/Setters in TypeScript.
open_questions.description: Explain Getters/Setters in TypeScript.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain Getters/Setters in TypeScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, getters and setters are special methods used to read and modify the properties of an object. They provide a way to define accessors on object properties, allowing for more controlled and flexible property access and mutation. class Person { private _name: string; get name(): string { return this._name; } set name(newName: string) { if (newName.length > 0) { this._name = newName; } } } let person = new Person("Alice"); person.name = "Bob"; // Changed using setter
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name the two primary types of
open_questions.description: Name the two primary types of modules in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name the two primary types of modules in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Internal (File-Level) Modules: Introduction: Internal modules are created using TypeScript's module system within a single TypeScript file. They provide a way to encapsulate related code within the file itself. Internal modules are also referred to as "file-level modules" or "namespaces." Syntax: Internal modules are defined using the namespace keyword (or using the ES6 module syntax), and code within them is encapsulated. // Internal module (namespace) example namespace MyNamespace { export function greet(name: string) { console.log(`Hello, ${name}!`); } } External (Ambient) Modules: Introduction: External modules are used to organize code across multiple files and are more commonly used in modern TypeScript projects. They are also known as "ambient modules" or "ES6 modules." Syntax: External modules use the export and import keywords to define and import code from other files. // ModuleA.ts export const message = "Hello from ModuleA"; // ModuleB.ts import { message } from "./ModuleA"; console.log(message); // "Hello from ModuleA"
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Namespaces in TypeScript
open_questions.description: What are namespaces in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are namespaces in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, namespaces (formerly known as "internal modules") are a way to encapsulate and organize related code within a single file or across multiple files. Namespaces provide a level of modularity and prevent naming conflicts by allowing you to group related functions, classes, variables, or other code constructs under a common namespace name. Example: // Definition namespace MyNamespace { export function someFunction() { // ... } } // Usage MyNamespace.someFunction();
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between extends and implements
open_questions.description: What is the difference between extends and implements in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between extends and implements in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In TypeScript, extends is used for class inheritance, allowing a class to inherit properties and methods from another class, thereby establishing a subclass-superclass relationship. In contrast, implements is used when a class wants to adhere to the structure defined by an interface, ensuring that it implements all the properties and methods of the interface. // Using extends for inheritance class Animal { eat() { console.log("Eating"); } } class Dog extends Animal { bark() { console.log("Woof!"); } } // Using implements for interface adherence interface Movable { move(): void; } class Car implements Movable { move() { console.log("Car is moving"); } }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The symbol type in TypeScript.
open_questions.description: Explain the symbol type in TypeScript.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the symbol type in TypeScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A symbol in TypeScript (and JavaScript) is a unique and immutable primitive value used primarily as a key for object properties to avoid name collisions. Each time a symbol is created, it is distinct from other symbols, even if they have the same description. Symbols are created using the Symbol() function and can be used to define object properties that are not easily accessible or overridden by other code. let myUniqueKey = Symbol("unique_property"); let myObject = { [myUniqueKey]: "This is a unique property" }; console.log(myObject[myUniqueKey]); // Outputs: "This is a unique property"
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: "module resolution" in TypeScript.
open_questions.description: Explain "module resolution" in TypeScript.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain "module resolution" in TypeScript.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Module resolution in TypeScript determines how the compiler finds and loads external modules or libraries. There are two primary strategies: "Node.js" and "Classic." Node.js module resolution is used for CommonJS modules, while Classic module resolution is used for AMD and System modules. Node.js resolution follows Node.js's module resolution algorithm, while Classic resolution uses relative and absolute paths.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Triple-slash directives
open_questions.description: What are triple-slash directives?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are triple-slash directives?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Triple-slash directives in TypeScript are single-line comments containing a single XML tag. They are used to give instructions to the compiler and are only valid at the top of their containing file. Triple-slash directives serve specific purposes, such as declaring dependencies on other files or adjusting compiler settings. The most common triple-slash directive is the reference directive. It is used to declare dependencies on other files. /// <reference path="anotherFile.ts" />
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A generic type in TypeScript
open_questions.description: What is a generic type in TypeScript?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a generic type in TypeScript?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A generic type in TypeScript is a type that can work with multiple data types while preserving type safety. It allows you to create functions, classes, or interfaces that can operate on values of different types without knowing those types in advance. Generic types are defined using a placeholder type parameter enclosed in angle brackets (<T> by convention), which represents the actual type that will be provided when the generic type is used. Example: function swap<T>(a: T, b: T): [T, T] { return [b, a]; } const [x, y] = swap(10, 20); // x is 20, y is 10 const [str1, str2] = swap("Hello", "World"); // str1 is "World", str2 is "Hello"
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name some use cases when generics
open_questions.description: Name some use cases when generics can be useful?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name some use cases when generics can be useful?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Reusability: Generics allow you to write code that can be reused for different data types, reducing code duplication. Type Safety: They provide type safety by ensuring that the input data types match the expected types, catching errors at compile time. Flexibility: Generics make your code more flexible, as they allow you to work with a wide range of data types without sacrificing type checking. Collections: Generics are commonly used when working with data structures like arrays, lists, and dictionaries that can contain elements of varying types.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Transpilation
open_questions.description: What is transpilation?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is transpilation?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Transpilation is a process in computer programming where source code written in one programming language is converted into equivalent code in another language. Unlike compilation, which typically translates high-level code into machine code or a lower-level language, transpilation converts code from one high-level language to another. In the case of TypeScript, which is a superset of JavaScript, the TypeScript code is transpiled into plain JavaScript code. This transpilation process allows developers to use TypeScript's static typing and additional features while still generating code that can be executed in any JavaScript runtime environment.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice
